section.title: Why submit your code?

listitem.para: Your code will be supported by the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; team... but of course, you can still help!
There is no need to merge your changes or resolve conflicts when updating from SVN. Since your code is already in there, updating should be straightforward.
Many people will benefit from your work!

section.para: However, if your code is very specific to your needs, or it does not interfere with the rest of the source, then you might prefer to keep it for yourself. Nevertheless, remember that &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; code is subject to the GNU GPL license.

section.title: Before you submit new code
section.para: If you want to develop a new feature, please get in touch with the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; Team to talk about it first. By doing so, we can mutualize our development resources and make your effort beneficial to the entire community of users.
Also, don't forget that &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; is deployed in many different places in different organizations. So make sure that your specifications are generalized enough to fit the needs of many.
Please test your code. Today, there is no code validation tool or regression tests on &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME;, so please make sure your code is consistent and fully tested before you submit it.
Last, the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; Team is here to help! We can provide you with useful guidelines and tips, so don't hesitate to talk to us.

section.title: Code Submission
section.para: The simpler way to submit your code to the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; team is to provide a patch, via the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; patch manager!

To create a patch, you can do the following: go in the 'httpd' directory, and type: cvs diff -c * > my_cvs_patch. You may also only select the files that concern the patch. Then make a 'tar' including the cvs diff and potentially new files you added, then compress it.
Once it is created, you can submit the patch with the Patch manager of the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; project.
